natural problem: Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.$
natural solution: From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\

&= \frac{2x - 3y}{13} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{4x - 6y}{13} \\ \frac{-6x + 9y}{13} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{4x - 6y}{13} \\ \frac{-6x + 9y}{13} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [2, -3]"
and h1 : "proj v = outer v v / (v \<bullet> v)"
shows  "proj v = matrix ([[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]])"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \frac{2x - 3y}{13} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{4x - 6y}{13} \\ \frac{-6x + 9y}{13} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{4x - 6y}{13} \\ \frac{-6x + 9y}{13} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [2, -3]"
and h1 : "proj v = outer v v / (v \<bullet> v)"
shows  "proj v = matrix ([[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a vector v = [2, -3], find the projection matrix of v, denoted as proj v, which is computed as the outer product of v with itself divided by the dot product of v with itself. The final answer is the matrix [[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]].

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [2, -3]"
and h1 : "P = outer_prod v v / (v \<bullet> v)"
shows  "P = matrix [[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]]"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \frac{2x - 3y}{13} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{4x - 6y}{13} \\ \frac{-6x + 9y}{13} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{4x - 6y}{13} \\ \frac{-6x + 9y}{13} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "real^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [2, -3]"
and h1 : "P = outer_prod v v / (v \<bullet> v)"
shows  "P = matrix [[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given the 2D vector $v = [2, -3]$, construct a matrix $P$ which is the outer product of $v$ with itself, normalized by the dot product of $v$ with itself. Find the entries of the matrix $P$. The final answer should be $P = \begin{bmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{bmatrix}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [2, -3]"
and h1 : "P = (1 / (v \<bullet> v)) * (outer v v)"
shows  "P = matrix [[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]]"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \frac{2x - 3y}{13} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{4x - 6y}{13} \\ \frac{-6x + 9y}{13} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{4x - 6y}{13} \\ \frac{-6x + 9y}{13} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "real^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [2, -3]"
and h1 : "P = (1 / (v \<bullet> v)) * (outer v v)"
shows  "P = matrix [[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given a vector v with elements [2, -3], find the matrix P which is computed as the outer product of v with itself, divided by the dot product of v with itself. The final answer is the matrix [[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]].

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [2, -3]"
shows  "proj_matrix v = (1 / 13) *\<^sub>R (matrix [[4, -6], [-6, 9]])"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \frac{2x - 3y}{13} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{4x - 6y}{13} \\ \frac{-6x + 9y}{13} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{4x - 6y}{13} \\ \frac{-6x + 9y}{13} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [2, -3]"
shows  "proj_matrix v = (1 / 13) *\<^sub>R (matrix [[4, -6], [-6, 9]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the projection matrix of the vector [2, -3]. The final answer is $\frac{1}{13}$ times the matrix [[4, -6], [-6, 9]].

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [2, -3]"
and h1 : "P = (1 / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R outer v v"
shows  "P = matrix [[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]]"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\

theorem
fixes v :: "real^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [2, -3]"
and h1 : "P = (1 / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R outer v v"
shows  "P = matrix [[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given a vector v = [2, -3], find a projection matrix P that is calculated as P = (1 / (v . v)) * v x v (where "." is the dot product and "x" is the outer product). Verify that the resulting matrix P is [[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]].

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real ^2"
and P :: "real ^2 ^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [2, -3]"
and h1 : "P = ((outer v v) / (v \<bullet> v))"
shows  "P = matrix([[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]])"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\

theorem
fixes v :: "real ^2"
and P :: "real ^2 ^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [2, -3]"
and h1 : "P = ((outer v v) / (v \<bullet> v))"
shows  "P = matrix([[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given a vector $v = [2, -3]$, find the projection matrix $P$ which is the outer product of $v$ divided by the dot product of $v$ with itself. The matrix $P$ should be $\left[\begin{array}{cc} \frac{4}{13} & -\frac{6}{13} \\ -\frac{6}{13} & \frac{9}{13} \end{array}\right]$.

(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\

theorem
fixes v :: "real^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [2, -3]"
and h1 : "P = (1 / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R outer v v"
shows  "P = matrix([[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a vector v with components 2 and -3, calculate the matrix P defined as the outer product of v and v divided by the dot product of v and v. Verify that the calculated matrix P is equal to the matrix with first row [4/13, -6/13] and second row [-6/13, 9/13].

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes u v :: "real^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "u = vector [2, -3]"
and h1 : "P = outer_prod u u / (u \<bullet> u)"
shows  "P = matrix [[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]]"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}

 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \frac{2x - 3y}{13} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{4x - 6y}{13} \\ \frac{-6x + 9y}{13} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{4x - 6y}{13} \\ \frac{-6x + 9y}{13} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes u v :: "real^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "u = vector [2, -3]"
and h1 : "P = outer_prod u u / (u \<bullet> u)"
shows  "P = matrix [[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given the vector $u = [2, -3]$, calculate the matrix $P$, which is the outer product of $u$ with itself, divided by the dot product of $u$ with itself. The final answer is the matrix $[[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]]$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "real^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [2, -3]"
and h1 : "P = ((1 / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R (outer v v))"
shows  "P = matrix([[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]])"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \frac{2x - 3y}{13} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{4x - 6y}{13} \\ \frac{-6x + 9y}{13} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{4x - 6y}{13} \\ \frac{-6x + 9y}{13} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "real^2" and P :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [2, -3]"
and h1 : "P = ((1 / (v \<bullet> v)) *\<^sub>R (outer v v))"
shows  "P = matrix([[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given a vector $v$ defined as $v = [2, -3]$, calculate the projection matrix $P$ defined as $P = \frac{1}{v \cdot v} vv^T$. What is $P$? The final answer is $\begin{bmatrix} \frac{4}{13} & -\frac{6}{13} \\ -\frac{6}{13} & \frac{9}{13} \end{bmatrix}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2" and v :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [2, -3]"
and h1 : "A = matrix([[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]])"
and h2 : "A *v v = v"
shows  "A = matrix([[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]])"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the matrix that corresponds to projecting onto the vector $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 From the projection formula, the projection of $\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}$ onto $\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}$ is \begin{align} \operatorname{proj}_{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} &= \frac{\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}}{\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix}} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
 &= \frac{2x - 3y}{13} \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{pmatrix} \\ &= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{4x - 6y}{13} \\ \frac{-6x + 9y}{13} \end{pmatrix}. \end{align}To find the matrix for the projection, we write this vector as the product of a matrix and the vector $\begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}$: \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{4x - 6y}{13} \\ \frac{-6x + 9y}{13} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x \\y \end{pmatrix}.\]Thus, the matrix for this transformation is $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4/13 & -6/13 \\ -6/13 & 9/13 \end{pmatrix}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2" and v :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "v = vector [2, -3]"
and h1 : "A = matrix([[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]])"
and h2 : "A *v v = v"
shows  "A = matrix([[4/13, -6/13], [-6/13, 9/13]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a 2x2 matrix $A=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{4}{13} & -\frac{6}{13} \\ -\frac{6}{13} & \frac{9}{13} \end{bmatrix}$ and a vector $v = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \end{bmatrix}$ such that $Av = v$, find the matrix $A$. The final answer is $A=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{4}{13} & -\frac{6}{13} \\ -\frac{6}{13} & \frac{9}{13} \end{bmatrix}$.
